column1: Let us turn to another example in a different branch of science. Whichever of our modern discoveries we may consider to be the most startling and important
column2: there can I think be no doubt that the most beautiful is that of the spectroscope. It has enabled us to do that which but a few years before its introduction was taken for the very type of the impossible
column4: to study the chemical composition of the stars; and it is giving us clearer and clearer insight every day into the condition of the great luminary which forms the center of our system. Still
column5: however beautiful and interesting such results may be
column6: it might well be thought that they could never have any practical application
column7: and that the spectroscope at least would remain an instrument of science
